Mike Bartoli
Aloke Desai
CS1595b
Writeup


We decided that the most concrete analysis would consider all
combinations of the two sets of parameters, so we took the cartesian
product of the two sets of possible values for our two parameters and
considered the words 'dog' and 'car', in an effort to uncover any high
level patterns in the results. 




From this we notice the similarities between COSINE and EUCLIDEAN,
which both share the same ordered output of words for PMI, TF, and
TFIDF. 

For example, for 'dog'

SIM: dog	TFIDF	COSINE
terrier	0.42509918446198813
breed	0.30965486946076354
dogs	0.2978623568562068
inu	0.2960605445292419
spitz	0.2616614799722562
breeds	0.2246772864593597
worries	0.22302501223604174
cat	0.22193447670667646
sled	0.2110237730911904
morality	0.2073245266814331


SIM: dog	TFIDF	EUCLIDEAN
terrier	1.072288035499802
breed	1.175027770343525
dogs	1.1850212176529116
inu	1.186540732946627
spitz	1.215186010475553
breeds	1.2452491425740009
worries	1.246575298779789
cat	1.2474498172618604
sled	1.2561657748154194
morality	1.259107202202075




and for 'car':


SIM: car	TFIDF	COSINE
kia	0.3356925656266164
motor	0.313984441957168
volkswagen	0.30584031732086236
racecar	0.28697482282001713
racing	0.2818757082502647
formula	0.27819760511432734
splinter	0.27818153432320686
artificially	0.27403890813535214
audi	0.26529367359685413
saab	0.2501651157717149


SIM: car	TFIDF	EUCLIDEAN
kia	1.152655572470271
motor	1.171337319513754
volkswagen	1.1782696488318272
racecar	1.1941735026201046
racing	1.1984358904419852
formula	1.2015010569164508
splinter	1.2015144324366596
artificially	1.2049573368917663
audi	1.2121933231981998
saab	1.2246100475076025


we can observe that the order between EUCLIDEAN and COSINE are the
same. 


L1 seems to produce a set of words significantly
differnt from the most similar words from {PMI,TF,TFIDF} x {COSINE,
EUCLIDEAN}. It's interesting to note that the order of word similarity
for PMI COSINE and PMI EUCLIDEAN is the same. 

Looking at cases for 'dog' we observe:

SIM: dog	PMI	L1
toki	17.2182469684865
heliocheilus	17.24767942016018
tirana	17.33404917779127
zlatko	17.342294704819622
shrewsbury	17.346762583505072
marquion	17.373460777901993
hesdin	17.373460777901993
pas	17.373460777901993
pernes	17.373460777901993
grasse	17.373460777901993

SIM: dog	PMI	EUCLIDEAN
hooch	1.3216996997948007
cat	1.3243766216864623
breeds	1.3276990873830525
terrier	1.3277677871835463
sled	1.3279033725201468
dogs	1.3307347806569962
whiskers	1.332225854165926
breed	1.3370471371642523
hunting	1.3404339114850896
herding	1.3448002315153629

Looking at cases for 'car' we observe similar results. 

SIM: car	PMI	L1
toki	20.829200681933134
heliocheilus	20.858633133606812
tirana	20.945002891237902
zlatko	20.953248418266252
shrewsbury	20.957716296951705
marquion	20.984414491348627
hesdin	20.984414491348627
pas	20.984414491348627
pernes	20.984414491348627
grasse	20.984414491348627

SIM: car	PMI	EUCLIDEAN
volkswagen	1.3001426050259974
driver	1.3093136008244728
motor	1.312846247508739
cars	1.3151634452315373
kia	1.3222636766315645
racing	1.3287801720259838
train	1.3289463565807504
peugeot	1.3299876762739389
automobile	1.3327999552327894
formula	1.3342815000132722


Additionally, from the cases above, we see that PMI seems to give us
slightly more relevant results in comparison with EUCLIDEAN. For
example, with both cases for 'car' and 'dog' all our output was
related to our word, but with TFIDF we had a couple words that were
not related. 

It also appears that, in general, TF leads to the least relevant
results.

For example, using 'car' we observe:

SIM: car	TF	COSINE
name	0.7115010685515202
thought	0.7019796267829959
american	0.6943994228676311
person	0.6924053731064784
believed	0.6886500205688562
member	0.6781602681419805
called	0.6773268715853057
version	0.6767646109731832
home	0.675446354703982
named	0.6752543680020847

SIM: car	TFIDF	COSINE
kia	0.3356925656266164
motor	0.313984441957168
volkswagen	0.30584031732086236
racecar	0.28697482282001713
racing	0.2818757082502647
formula	0.27819760511432734
splinter	0.27818153432320686
artificially	0.27403890813535214
audi	0.26529367359685413
saab	0.2501651157717149




Appendix:

Below are results for cartesian product of our two sets of parameters
{PMI,TF,TFIDF} and {COSINE, EUCLIDEAN, L1} for input word 'car':

SIM: car	PMI	COSINE
volkswagen	0.15481460329810737
driver	0.14284894734802703
motor	0.13821736520111197
cars	0.13517255616335716
kia	0.1258093847303895
racing	0.11717162721529936
train	0.11695079066537521
peugeot	0.11556639047972471
automobile	0.1118221396657387
formula	0.1098464393611666

name	0.7115010685515202
